questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is bought to the physician by her mother as she got complaints from school that her daughter doesn't speak in school but at home, she speaks freely. Her mother told that she got divorced 2 months back and her child started developing these behavioral changes after that. Physical and neurological examination is normal. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Selective Mutism Children with selective mutism usually speak freely at home , and only exhibit symptoms when under social pressure either in school or other social situations. Some children seem predisposed to selective mutism after early emotional or physical trauma as seen in this patient. For diagnosis duration of symptoms should be more than 1 month .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. There is no regression of milestones , and no decrease in head circumference so not Rett's syndrome. Option: C. There is no evidence of the psychosis , such as hallucinations , that would characterize schizophrenia . Option: D. Criteria of ADHD not fulfilled as there is No hyperactivity , impulsivity , or attention deficit so no ADHD.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is referred for evaluation because he has not started walking. He readily comes with you to the examining room and starts arranging blocks in a straight line and then disturbing them, he does this continuously. After about 10 minutes, you attempt to take the toy from him and he becomes extremely upset, making an insistent, piercing cry. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Autistic disorder This boy’s behavior is characteristic of autistic disorder . He suffers from impaired social interactions and attachments, restricted interests and behaviors , and impaired communication . (He doesn’t interact with the physician, becomes preoccupied with a toy to an abnormal degree, and screams when the toy is taken away)

Highyeild:

DSM-5 collapses the core diagnostic impairments into two domains: Deficits in social communication Restricted and repetitive behaviors . Aberrant language development and usage are no longer considered a core feature of autism spectrum disorder.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. He is not primarily negativistic and hostile as in oppositional defiant disorder . Option: B. He is not aggressive, destructive, deceitful , or in violation of rules , as in conduct disorder . Option: C. He does not become upset when separated from his mother , as in separation anxiety disorder .

Extraedge:

Autism Spectrum Disorder consists of: Autism Rett’s syndrome: normal development for at least 6 months , followed by stereotyped hand movements , a loss of purposeful motions, diminishing social engagement , poor coordination, and decreasing language use. Microcephaly is seen. Childhood disintegrative disorder (Heller’s Syndrome): Development progresses normally for 2 years , after which loss of previously acquired skills( loss of bladder or bowel control ). Asperger’s disorder : Impairment in social relatedness and repetitive and stereotyped patterns of behavior, but cognitive abilities and significant adaptive skills are age-appropriate(Have Normal I.Q.)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought as he lost previously acquired skills in communication and was no longer toilet trained. By age 2, he was speaking in sentences, and his development appeared to be proceeding appropriately. At 3½ years of age, he abruptly exhibited a period of marked behavioral regression shortly after the birth of a sibling, became more withdrawn and less interested in social interaction, exhibiting various self-stimulatory behaviors repeatedly. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Childhood disintegrative disorder Childhood disintegrative disorder is characterized by marked regression in several areas of functioning after at least 2 years of apparently normal development. It can be precipitated by some life event. Childhood disintegrative disorder is also called Heller’s syndrome .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Rett syndrome - development is normal till 5 months after which it starts regressing. Option C: Asperger's syndrome - there is no language and cognitive deficit. Option D : Tourette syndrome- presents with motor and vocal tics and there is no regression of milestones in it.

Extraedge:

Microcephaly is seen. questions.text: A 4-year-old male child presented to OPD by his parents. His parents complained that their child has difficulty talking, and he also has difficulty walking. Till 2 years of age, everything was fine. Then gradually he developed a problem. On examination the IQ of the child is low, he has an intellectual disability. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heller syndrome Also known as childhood disintegrative disorder . Normal growth occurs up to 2 years of age, after that regression of milestones occurs.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: B. Rett Syndrome- child growth is normal up to 5 months after that regression occurs between 5-48 months. Option: C. questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought up by her parents due to problems at school where she frequently uses the wrong verb tense. Her parents report that she was slow to speak as a toddler. The girl has a friend with whom she plays after school. On examination, the patient's speech is clear, but her vocabulary is limited and she uses simple sentences. She can count to 10 slowly. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Language disorder This patient most likely has a language disorder (LD), characterized by Persistent difficulties in comprehension (receptive) Persistent difficulties in the production (expression) of spoken and written language. It may involve the rules (grammar, syntax, morphology), content (vocabulary), and/or functional use of language. As in this patient, typical symptoms include a markedly limited vocabulary , errors in tense , and difficulty producing sentences with developmentally appropriate length and complexity.

Highyeild:

LDs interfere with academic functioning. Increase the risk for specific learning disorders (eg, reading and writing disabilities) Early intervention, including structured language therapy and stimulating language development at school and home, is beneficial and improves outcomes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Childhood-onset fluency disorder, also known as stuttering , is an impairment in the fluency of speech production. Option: C. Social (pragmatic) communication disorder is characterized by persistent difficulty in the social use of verbal and nonverbal communication . This girl's ability to interact socially with peers and family makes this diagnosis less likely. Option: D. As the demands of reading and writing increase, this patient will be at risk for a comorbid learning disorder. At this time, however, there is insufficient evidence to make this diagnosis, as it requires the use of standardized achievement testing.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought by his parents due to unusual behavior and concerns about his intellectual development as he uses only single words and mumbles. When he attended preschool, he refused to speak and preferred to play with toy cars by himself. During the examination, he doesn’t have eye contact and sits in the corner lining up toy cars. When stopped, he has a temper tantrum and begins to hit his head. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Autism spectrum disorder This child's social isolation, repetitive stereotypical movements (eg, head banging), and fixated interest in cars are suggestive of autism spectrum disorder (ASD). ASD presents in early childhood and is 4 times more common in males .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. In Language disorder (ie, deficits in comprehension or production) nonverbal communication (eg, eye contact) should be normal . This child's lack of social interaction and restricted interests are more consistent with ASD. Option: C. Although this child engages in head banging, he does not display other characteristic self-mutilating behaviors or features typical of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome (eg, biting his fingers and tongue, dystonia, writhing movements, delayed motor development, nephrolithiasis, gout). Option: D. Children with selective mutism usually speak freely at home , and only exhibit symptoms when under social pressure either in school or other social situations.

Extraedge:

Autism Spectrum Disorder consists of: Autism Rett’s syndrome: normal development for at least 6 months , followed by stereotyped hand movements , a loss of purposeful motions, diminishing social engagement , poor coordination, and decreasing language use. Microcephaly is seen. Childhood disintegrative disorder (Heller’s Syndrome): Development progresses normally for 2 years , after which loss of previously acquired skills( loss of bladder or bowel control ). Asperger’s disorder : Impairment in social relatedness and repetitive and stereotyped patterns of behavior, but cognitive abilities and significant adaptive skills are age-appropriate(Have Normal I.Q.)

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought by his mother for a check-up as he keeps playing by himself, has a 1-word vocabulary of "no," and does not yet say "mama," "dada," or "bye-bye". Rest all milestones are achieved on time. On examination, he does not make eye contact, respond to his name, or follow the doctor's gaze when toys are pointed out to him. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Autism spectrum disorder This child's delayed language development , unresponsiveness to his name, and impaired social communication and interaction are concerns for autism spectrum disorder (ASD). A key feature of ASD in children this age is the absence of joint attention (ie, spontaneous attempt to share interests with others by eye gazing and pointing at objects). Other signs of autism include an insistence on routines , fixated interests (eg, playing exclusively with 1 toy, no interest in others or exploring the world), and repetitive movements (eg, rocking, hand flapping).

Highyeild:

Language dysfunction in ASD is variable and can range from subtle abnormalities of pitch and odd word choice to the absence of functional speech . Language delay without an attempt to compensate through nonverbal means of communication is characteristic of ASD . Management of ASD commonly includes speech therapy , behavioral therapy, educational interventions, and occupational therapy .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Children with selective mutism usually speak freely at home , and only exhibit symptoms when under social pressure either in school or other social situations. Option: C. This patient's deficits in social responsiveness and interaction are more suggestive of ASD. Children with isolated intellectual disabilities typically exhibit social responsiveness appropriate to their developmental level. Option: D. In Language disorder (ie, deficits in comprehension or production) nonverbal communication (eg, eye contact) should be normal . This child's lack of social interaction and restricted interests are more consistent with ASD.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child was bought by his parents as he was noted to have difficulties in peer interaction, joining activities, and following the rules. They also noted that he had difficulties in making friends and playing sports with the other students, and he often played alone and spent time alone at lunch and recess. Psychological testing revealed an IQ within the normal range. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Asperger's disorder The points favoring the diagnosis of Asperger’s are: As there is no significant delay in language and cognitive development . There is an impairment in social interaction (difficulties in making friends and playing sports with the other students, often playing alone and spending time alone). Doesn't manifest with mental retardation .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Tourette syndrome - vocal and motor tics should be present which is not seen in this child. Option: C. ADHD - hyperactivity, impulsivity, attention deficit. Not seen in this child. Option: D. Down syndrome -there is mental retardation and other physical features present like upward slanted eyes, and simian crease.

Extraedge:

Microcephaly is seen.
